abstract.p: Letter from Barbara Wong says Henry Wong, in his May 24 Op-Ed, pinpoints frustrations of immigrant workers in garment industry

block.p: Henry Wong (Op-Ed, May 24) pinpoints the frustrations of immigrant workers in the garment industry.

I, too, was a child who grew up in the shadows of the garment factories of Chinatown. I guess I can consider myself lucky, since the garment factories in the 1970's and 80's provided a semblance of allowing my mother, a seamstress, the slight hope of earning a wage slightly above the poverty level.
Henry Wong (Op-Ed, May 24) pinpoints the frustrations of immigrant workers in the garment industry.

I, too, was a child who grew up in the shadows of the garment factories of Chinatown. I guess I can consider myself lucky, since the garment factories in the 1970's and 80's provided a semblance of allowing my mother, a seamstress, the slight hope of earning a wage slightly above the poverty level.

It is an impossible situation for garment factories to remain competitive within this new global economy. But what alternatives are there, and who can help these immigrant workers? Those are the questions the labor movement should concentrate on.
